Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I sat at the round table, my conference badge still clipped to my jacket, surrounded by colleagues from the pharmacy workshop. The air buzzed with talk of new prescription guidelines, and I felt proud to be here, staying current for my patients. When lunch arrived, platters of sandwiches and salads were set out, but as I scanned the labels, my heart sank—none bore the kosher certification I needed. I could almost hear my mother’s voice reminding me of the importance of keeping kosher, a value woven into my daily life. Yet, here I was, expected to network, to join in, to be part of the team. My stomach tightened as I weighed the professional expectation to participate fully against my commitment to my faith. The laughter and chatter around me grew louder, and I felt the pressure mounting, torn between two worlds that suddenly seemed impossibly far apart.
